30 30

Celebrating 30 Years of AIDS Vancouver

The 30 30 campaign was created in 2013 to celebrate AIDS Vancouver’s 30th anniversary. The campaign pieces together the dynamic history of HIV in Vancouver, told by and for those who where there.

1987

1988

A love Story

In 1988

  • The 1988 Winter Olympics are held in Calgary, Alberta, Canada. LINK
  • Pan Am Flight 103 blows up over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing 270 people. LINK
  • August 20 – The Iran–Iraq War ends, with an estimated one million lives lost. LINK

Local

  • Embalmers fear AIDS risk. Apr 4, 1988. Landriault said: They can fire me tomorrow if they force me to do an AIDS case. LINK
  • A Change for the Better - AIDS Vancouver opens membership. May 1988. LINK
  • Vander Zalm Axes Funds for AZT '...Bill Vander Zalm’s announced that people with AIDS in British Columbia would have to pay up to $2,000.00 per year for the widely used AIDS drug AZT.' LINK
  • Cartoon. Vancouver Western News. May 18, 1988 LINK

Statistics

  • 1,204 Canadians diagnosed with AIDS during this year.
  • 660 HIV deaths reported. LINK
  • 800,000 worldwide AIDS deaths.

Global

  • The number of women living in sub-Saharan Africa with HIV/AIDS exceeds that of men. LINK
  • The first needle-exchange program in North America is established in Washington. LINK
  • First World Aids Day. LINK
  • International AIDS Society Formed. LINK

National

  • CAS becomes a federally-registered charity and moves to Ottawa, operating with three employees. LINK
  • 'Safer Sex Guidelines: A Resource Document for Educators and Counsellors' was published by CAS, which were the first safe sex guidelines for Canada. LINK
1989

AIDS Vancouver - Prevent. Act. Support.

AIDS Vancouver plays a special role in providing quality health care to people affected by HIV/AIDS living in the Lower Mainland. It is clearly more than just a community health care organization. It is an organization whose presence and continued strength is essential to the quality for life of this community and of each individual and family who draws on its services. Our Agency is a vital community asset which everyone affected by HIV/AIDS can share, and in which we all have a stake.

Visit us at aidsvancouver.org

2013 © AIDS Vancouver
